source: UKIP, which won May's election, spent £2,956,737, while the Tories' campaign expenditure was £2,980,815,The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs - Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339.The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to polling day, 22 May.UKIP's campaign spending works out at 68p for each of their 4,376,635 votes. For Labour it is 26p per vote, the Conservatives 79p and the Lib Dems, who lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, £1.45. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249 on its campaign - 43p for each of its 1,255,573 votes.Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning, the Electoral Commission said.All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.
summary: In the provided passage, the core pieces of information are campaign expenditures for several political parties in the UK's May election for the European Parliament. UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives at £2,980,815, Labour at £1,027,339, Lib Dems at £1,580,575, and the Green Party at £534,249. The Lib Dems lost all but one of their MEPs, while Labour came second. The spending per vote for each party was UKIP at 68p, Labour at 26p, Conservatives at 79p, Lib Dems at £1.45, and the Green Party at 43p. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, and all but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

summary: UKIP, the winning party in May's election, spent £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour, the second-place party, spent £1,027,339. UKIP's campaign spending was 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p, the Conservatives' was 79p, and the Lib Dems' was £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote) and the SNP spent £267,372. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election campaign. The campaign period was from 23 January to polling day, 22 May.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The passage details campaign spending for the May European Parliament elections in the UK. UKIP, the winning party, spent £2,956,737, slightly less than the Conservatives at £2,980,815. Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, while the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 but lost all but one of their MEPs. The Green Party, finishing fourth, spent £534,249. When calculated per vote received, UKIP spent 68p, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, and Lib Dems £1.45. The top six highest-spending parties, including the SNP, spent a total of £9,347,087. All parties except Labour increased their spending compared to the 2009 European election campaign.

summary: The passage details the campaign expenditure of several UK political parties during the 2014 European Parliament election. UKIP, the winning party, spent nearly £3 million, closely followed by the Tories. The Lib Dems, despite spending over £1.5 million, lost most of their MEPs. Labour, in second place, spent just over £1 million, making it the most cost-effective campaign in terms of cost per vote. The Green Party and SNP also spent significantly less than the top two parties. All parties, except Labour, increased their spending compared to the 2009 election.

UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives (£2,980,815), Labour (£1,027,339), and the Liberal Democrats (£1,580,575). The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. The total expenditure by these six parties was £9,347,087. Compared to the 2009 election, all parties except Labour spent more money. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, the Conservatives 79p, Labour 26p, and the Lib Dems £1.45 per vote. The Lib Dems lost most of their seats, while UKIP won.

The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The campaign period was from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending was 68p per vote, Labour's 26p, the Conservatives' 79p, and the Lib Dems' £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the top six parties spent a total of £9,347,087. All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.
